chapter_title: Control the Options: Get Others to Play with the Cards You Deal
summary: In this chapter, Greene emphasizes the importance of controlling the narrative and options presented to others. By offering a limited selection of choices, one can manipulate the decisions of rivals or subordinates to align with personal interests.

visual_theme.prompt: The Horns of a Bull as a symbol of dilemma, dramatic battlefield environment with tension, high-contrast lighting, dark and disruptive color palette, emotionally charged mood, surrealist art style.
visual_theme.style: Surreal and dramatic with a focus on control and manipulation

slides.section_body: The most effective deceptions offer the illusion of choice.
slides.quote: Your victims feel they are in control, but are actually your puppets.

slides.section_title: The Dilemma of Ivan the Terrible
slides.section_body: Ivan IV faced the boyars, who threatened his authority.
slides.quote: He offered his subjects a choice: grant him absolute power or face civil chaos.

slides.section_body: The power to dictate choices converts uncertainty into your advantage.
slides.quote: Whenever people feel they have a choice, they walk into your trap that much more easily.

slides.section_body: Take inspiration from Henry Kissinger, who crafted options in a way that always favored his preferred outcomes.
slides.quote: The one he preferred always seemed the best solution compared to the others.

slides.section_body: Milton H. Erickson cleverly forced patients into a corner by suggesting self-sabotage as an option.
slides.quote: Push them to 'choose' what you want them to do by appearing to advocate the opposite.

slides.section_body: John D. Rockefeller illustrated manipulation through the acquisition of transport companies.
slides.quote: Alter the playing field so that the only options the small oil producers had were the ones he gave them.

slides.section_body: Ambroise Vollard used scarcity as a means to urge action.
slides.quote: They had better grab what he was showing them, because tomorrow they would have to settle for something worse.

slides.section_body: Creating a situation where adversaries face conflicting choices ensures they will make a detrimental choice that favors you.
slides.quote: They have to answer the lawyerâ€™s questions, but whatever they say they hurt themselves.

slides.section_body: While controlling options can disguise you as a harbinger of power, drawbacks still exist.
slides.quote: It is usually more elegant to give people the illusion of choice.

slides.section_body: Ultimately, providing the illusion of choice solidifies your control.
slides.quote: If you can get the bird to walk into the cage on its own, it will sing that much more prettily.
